description.narrative: Promotion and protection of human rights and Democracy.
FL §06.32.08.40 DIGNITY - Danish Institute Against Torture

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: State mandated detention monitoring mechanisms and CSOs conduct effective monitoring of places of detention, the use of pre-trial detention is decreasing, and cases of torture are identified and causes, and dynamics of torture are better understood on the basis of research; there is a reduced reliance on confessional evidence by the judiciary

actual.value: Example of key achievement: As a result of trainings by local partner Children's Legal Rights and Development Center (CLRDC), 44 (10 men and 30 women) local municipal (barangay) authorities and social workers in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City, Philippines, have improved their knowledge about the national and international legal framework relating to children in the juvenile justice system, gained an understanding of the importance of a holistic and child-rights based approach to juvenile justice and their roles and duties as stakeholders in the juvenile justice system. In addition, a baseline study was conducted on the implementation of the Comprehensive National Juvenile Intervention Plan in the project site, Bagong Silang, setting the ground for engagement with duty-bearers on addressing gaps and challenges.

actual.value: Example of key achievement: As a result of trainings by local partner Children's Legal Rights and Development Center (CLRDC), 44 (10 men and 30 women) local municipal (barangay) authorities and social workers in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City, Philippines, have improved their knowledge about the national and international legal framework relating to children in the juvenile justice system, gained an understanding of the importance of a holistic and child-rights based approach to juvenile justice and their roles and duties as stakeholders in the juvenile justice system. In addition, a baseline study was conducted on the implementation of the Comprehensive National Juvenile Intervention Plan in the project site, Bagong Silang, setting the ground for engagement with duty-bearers on addressing gaps and challenges.

title.narrative: Duty bearers (States parties) in DIGNITY’s partner countries have further enhanced their compliance with the UNCAT, and international anti-torture standards have been developed further within the United Nations, hereby increasing the international protection of rights holders.

actual.value: Example of key achievement: As part of an international expert initiative, DIGNITY co-drafted the ‘Principles on Effective Interviewing for Investigations and Information gathering’. The Principles are firmly grounded in scientific evidence, which establishes that non-coercive methods for interviewing suspects are the most effective for gathering information, and empirical research, which shows that torture and ill-treatment are ineffective and counter-productive methods of questioning. The Principles reflect best practice and seek to set out a normative framework for effective interviewing by police and law enforcement, which respects the prohibition of torture and ill-treatment.

title.narrative: Local human rights and development NGOs in the Global South are capacitated to become sustainable partners and form strategic networks, including partners’ ability to undertake local and international advocacy based on knowledge generated from community-led interventions locally

actual.value: Example of key achievement: Based on the workshops hosted in 2019, the researchers in Kenya and Sri Lanka commenced data collection supported by DIGNITY. As the pandemic restricted movement and possibilities for data collection, the methodologies of the project were changed to online interviews and diary keeping. A key finding in this data is that both countries lack a formalized and functioning protection mechanism, and that local communities and activists often take on the role of offering protection and supporting survivors, which leaves the communities and activists in greater risk of authority-based reprisals and violence. A report on protection to the UNCAT review of Kenya was prepared, but the session was postponed.

title.narrative: Local human rights and development NGOs in the Global South are capacitated to become sustainable partners and form strategic networks, including partners’ ability to undertake local and international advocacy based on knowledge generated from community-led interventions locally

actual.value: Example of key achievement: Based on the workshops hosted in 2019, the researchers in Kenya and Sri Lanka commenced data collection supported by DIGNITY. As the pandemic restricted movement and possibilities for data collection, the methodologies of the project were changed to online interviews and diary keeping. A key finding in this data is that both countries lack a formalized and functioning protection mechanism, and that local communities and activists often take on the role of offering protection and supporting survivors, which leaves the communities and activists in greater risk of authority-based reprisals and violence. A report on protection to the UNCAT review of Kenya was prepared, but the session was postponed.

title.narrative: State authorities have capacity to investigate and prosecute cases of torture and apply pre-trial detention according to international standards; and non-state actors have capacity to medically and legally document cases of torture, as appropriate for different purposes (e.g. advocacy, criminal complaints)

actual.value: Example of key achievement: In Ukraine, 87 legal and health professionals from 46 NGOs who work with documentation of cases of torture and CIDTP have been identified. 45 legal/health professionals created a referral network and started to actively engage in sharing their cases and experiences with medicolegal documentation. The creation of the Facebook group followed by a two-week online training on medicolegal documentation which was conducted by DIGNITY in Ukraine. As a result of that, 11 cases were submitted to the judiciary with supporting strong documentation.

title.narrative: Inter-sectoral dialogue and prevention of violence programs assessed for impact in 8 cases (municipalities) and results used in fight against TOV in global advocacy work (WHO Violence Prevention Alliance and SDG 11.7 & 16.1)

actual.value: Example of key achievement: Local partner HURA has been in a pilot-assessment phase from Dec 2019 to Aug 2020, resulting in DIGNITY terminating the partnership with HURA (end Nov 2020). The reason was that HURA has not been able to take on the task to lead and facilitate a complex multisectoral urban violence development programme. HURA has however been able to perform as a service provider in relation to the prevention of Covid-19 in slum areas of Mbale municipality. All originally planned activities for 2020 were cancelled and reprogrammed due to Covid-19. The reprogramming involved the following: Formation of Covid-19 Emergency Response Committee (consisting of HURA and police), dissemination of Covid-19 prevention measures and mental health advice posters, support to police units with basic hand washing facilities (soap and water tanks)

title.narrative: Inter-sectoral dialogue and prevention of violence programs assessed for impact in 8 cases (municipalities) and results used in fight against TOV in global advocacy work (WHO Violence Prevention Alliance and SDG 11.7 & 16.1)

actual.value: Example of key achievement: Local partner HURA has been in a pilot-assessment phase from Dec 2019 to Aug 2020, resulting in DIGNITY terminating the partnership with HURA (end Nov 2020). The reason was that HURA has not been able to take on the task to lead and facilitate a complex multisectoral urban violence development programme. HURA has however been able to perform as a service provider in relation to the prevention of Covid-19 in slum areas of Mbale municipality. All originally planned activities for 2020 were cancelled and reprogrammed due to Covid-19. The reprogramming involved the following: Formation of Covid-19 Emergency Response Committee (consisting of HURA and police), dissemination of Covid-19 prevention measures and mental health advice posters, support to police units with basic hand washing facilities (soap and water tanks)

title.narrative: State and non-state actors demonstrate ownership and capability of practicing effective rehabilitation models

actual.value:
Example of key achievement: The number of direct and indirect trauma affected beneficiaries (women, men and children) that have been given access to and have benefitted from trauma informed Mental Health and Psychosocial Support services (MHPSS) (i.e. individual, family, group and community based) in 2020 is 27.391.
Brief breakdown follows: In MENA, 2.085 victims accessed e-services provided by DIGNITY’s local partners offering MHPSS treatment. Thus, an increased outreach to victims of torture and violence took place. In Africa, a total of 8.386 beneficiaries accessed treatment provided by DIGNITY and partners. Activities were conducted in Keyna, Ghana, South Africa and Uganda (cf. Evaluation 2020 for details). In East Europe (Ukraine) 41 survivors of torture and violence was identified and provided relevant medical and psychological treatment and legal support.

title.narrative: Rehabilitation models have been adjusted to global unmet needs, and show documented effect in local contexts

actual.value: Example of key achievements: Clinical data on DIGNITYs intervention has been collected on a regular basis throughout the reporting period together with partners. Complementary M&E methods to monitor clinical interventions as well as the impact of DIGNITYs training on participants (People Ways inspired) have been applied. Both tools support the further tailoring of clinical interventions to the needs of health professionals, partners and beneficiaries. See Evaluation 2020 for details.

title.narrative: Improved health and increased empowerment among survivors of torture and organised violence

actual.value: In Colombia, the DFC funded project completed an analysis of several characteristics in 15 project municipalities in 5 different departments, based in national data, completed. This included finalizing sampling strategy and questionnaire incl. programming for survey of mental health in vulnerable populations. In addition, local interviewers were trained in project departments (necessary due to corona travel restrictions within the country). Also, study of secondary traumatisation of interviewers was planned, questionnaire for survey (as part of a thesis project on secondary traumatization) was developed.
